metadata.title: Superior Potassium Ion Storage via Vertical MoS2 NanoRose with Expanded Interlayers on Graphene

sections.text:
FULL PAPER
1701471 (1 of 8) © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com small

sections.heading: Superior Potassium Ion Storage via Vertical MoS2 “Nano-Rose” with Expanded Interlayers on Graphene
sections.text: Keyu Xie, Kai Yuan, Xin Li, Wei Lu, Chao Shen, Chenglu Liang, Robert Vajtai,

sections.heading: Pulickel Ajayan, and Bingqing Wei*
sections.text:
Prof. K. Y. Xie, K. Yuan, X. Li, Dr. C. Shen, Prof. B. Q. Wei State Key Laboratory of Solidification Processing Center for Nano Energy Materials School of Materials Science and Engineering Northwestern Polytechnical University and Shaanxi Joint Laboratory of Graphene (NPU) Xi’an 710072, China E-mail: weib@udel.edu Prof. K. Y. Xie, C. Liang, Dr. R. Vajtai, Prof. P. Ajayan Department of Materials Science and Nano Engineering Rice University Houston, TX 77050, USA Dr. W. Lu University Research Facility in Materials Characterization and Device Fabrication The Hong Kong Polytechnic University Hong Kong 999077, China Prof. B. Q. Wei Department of Mechanical Engineering University of Delaware Newark, NJ, DE 19716, USA
The ORCID identification number(s) for the author(s) of this article can be found under https://doi.org/10.1002/smll.201701471.
DOI: 10.1002/smll.201701471
importance.[1–3] As one of the state-ofthe-art battery technologies, Li-ion battery (LIB) technology has made significant progress in revolutionizing the means of modern communications[4,5] and will undoubtedly continue to play a major role in the rapid development of electric vehicles and electric grids for years to come. However, in consideration of the limited resources of Li in earth crust (0.0017 wt%), LIBs will not be able to satisfy the large-scale energy storage requirements of the long-term future, and thus, new battery technologies based on earth-abundant elements are desperately needed.[6,7]
Consequently, other battery systerms (e.g., dual-ion batteries)[8,9] and other alkali metals with high abundance in the Earth’s crust (e.g., Na, 2.3 wt% and K, 2.09 wt%) have come into the view of
researchers.[10–13] Unfortunately, compared to its Na+ counterpart, the larger diameter of K+ (K+ vs Na+: 1.40 Å vs 1.00 Å) makes it a big challenge to find suitable host materials for reversible as well as fast K+ insertion/extraction.[14,15] As a result, while significant advances have been made in Na-ion battery (NIB) chemistry,[16,17] very few signs of progress were achieved in K-ion battery (KIB) chemistry in recent years.
Until now, only a few materials,[15,18–21] such as Prussian blue, K0.7Fe0.5Mn0.5O2, K0.3MnO2, FePO4, FeSO4F, 3,4,9,10-perylene-tetracarboxylicacid-dianhydride (PTCDA), have been reported as available cathode materials for nonaqueous KIBs, while graphite,[7,22] soft carbon,[23] hard carbon,[24] carbon black,[15] graphene,[25–27] Sn/C,[28] and K2Ti8O17[11] have been investigated as anode materials, and Sn foil[29] and mesocarbon microbead[30] have been reported as the anode for potassium-ion-based dual-ion batteries. More seriously, the electrochemical capacities of all these electrode materials mentioned above are rather unsatisfactory, especially those anode materials. For example, as a graphitic carbon material, reduced graphene oxide could deliver an initial reversible capacity up to 1057 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 for an NIB,[31] while it is only 222 mAh g−1 at 5 mA g−1 for a KIB, because of the insufficient interlayer distance for K+ insertion/extraction.[32] A Sn/C composite anode shows a representative specific capacity of ≈494 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 for NIB.[33] In contrast, when it was employed as an anode for KIB, this value is less than onethird (≈150 mAh g−1 at 25 mA g−1) of that of NIB, due to the
Potassium has its unique advantages over lithium or sodium as a charge carrier in rechargeable batteries. However, progresses in K-ion battery (KIB) chemistry have so far been hindered by lacking suitable electrode materials to host the relatively large K+ ions compared to its Li+ and Na+ counterparts. Herein, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) “roses” grown on reduced graphene oxide sheets (MoS2@rGO) are synthesized via a two-step solvothermal route. The as-synthesized MoS2@rGO composite, with expanded interlayer spacing of MoS2, chemically bonded between MoS2 and rGO, and a unique nanoarchitecture, displays the one of the best electrochemical performances to date as an anode material for nonaqueous KIBs. More importantly, a combined K+ storage mechanism of intercalation and conversion reaction is also revealed. The findings presented indicate the enormous potential of layered metal dichalcogenides as advanced electrode materials for high-performance KIBs and also provide new insights and understanding of K+ storage mechanism.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
To set up a sustainable energy economy of humanity society, a cheap and reliable energy storage technology is of vital
Small 2017, 1701471
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701471 (2 of 8)
extremely sluggish reaction kinetics.[28] Therefore, design and synthesis of the electrode materials with the capability to host the large-diameter K+ as well as provide fast reaction kinetics simultaneously for KIBs is a big challenge.
Recently, layered metal dichalcogenides have drawn significant attention and show great potential for electrochemical energy storage applications.[34–38] Among them, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is undoubtedly an emerging electrode material for battery applications.[39–42] The weak van der Waals interaction between layers in MoS2,[42] as well as the larger interlayer distance,[43] compared to the carbon-based anode materials, render it an ideal host for reversible and fast K+ insertion/ extraction in principle. However, to the best of our knowledge, no research has been reported to explore the potential application of MoS2 as an anode material for KIBs so for, though it has been widely investigated as an anode material for LIBs and NIBs.[44–46] Hence, the exploring of MoS2, a prototypical-layered metal dichalcogenide, as the anode material of KIBs would be urgent and interesting.
Previous work[36,47] devoted to using layered metal dichalcogenides as electrode materials for LIBs and NIBs has shown that the sophisticated materials and rational structural design are of great important to obtain the expected performances for battery applications. Experience learned from previous work can be summarized as below, and help us in conquering the intrinsic shortcomings of metal dichalcogenide-based electrode materials of KIBs: (1) Expanding the interlayer spacing of layered metal dichalcogenides themselves is in favor of alleviating the structural change upon ion insertion/extraction, and thus, enhancing the long-term cycle stability.[48,49] (2) Strongly coupling between these materials and highly conductive skeleton materials, such as graphene or carbon nanotube, is the key to boosting electrode kinetics as well as concurrently buffer the structural change during cycling,[50] which together lead to long cycle life and good rate capability. (3) Careful tuning the morphology of these materials at micro/nanoscale is also an efficient way to enhance the electrochemical performances of these materials.[40,51]
Based on the considerations mentioned above, we have developed a new two-step solvothermal strategy to synthesize ultrathin and ultrauniform rose-like MoS2 strongly coupled with reduced graphene oxide sheets (MoS2@rGO), which were derived from the highly uniform Mo-glycerate/rGO sheet precursor (MoG@rGO), and investigated the electrochemical performances of these composites as anodes for KIBs. These MoS2@rGO composites, with expanded interlayer distance of MoS2 itself, tightly coupling between these two components, as well as the unique architecture (petal-like MoS2 nanosheets vertically grown on graphene sheets), meet all the aforementioned requirements, and not surprisingly, deliver the highest specific capacity (679 mAh g−1 at 20 mA g−1) among all the reported data so far for KIB anode materials. Moreover, at the high current density of 100 mA g−1, the capacity of these MoS2@rGO anodes still maintained over 380 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles, exemplifying the importance of the rational and sophisticated design of electrode materials as well as opening up new opportunities for high-performance KIBs.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussions
sections.text:
Figure 1 schematically illustrates the synthesis strategy of MoS2@rGO via a two-step solvothermal method. In the first step, MoG homogeneous cover on the rGO sheets (MoG@rGO) by using molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) as the molybdenum source, graphene oxide as the precursor of the conductive matrix (rGO), and a certain amount of glycerol, isopropanol, together with water as the co-solvents. In the following step, the highly uniform MoG thin film gradually reacts with the sulfide ions released from the thiourea,[52] and transforms into the rose-like MoS2 with ultrathin nanosheet “petals.”
The morphology characteristics of the MoS2 @rGO composites were investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). As shown in Figure 2a, ultra-uniformly distributed MoS2 “roses” were grown upward on the whole
Small 2017, 1701471
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701471 (3 of 8)
rGO sheets. At higher magnifications (Figure 2b,c), it can be clearly seen that these MoS2 roses consist of ultrathin and upward nanosheets, usually less than 100 nm. Moreover, the elemental mapping images further confirm the homogeneous distribution of Mo, S, and C within the MoS2 @rGO composites (Figure 2d–f). Similar morphology characteristics can also be observed in the low magnification transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Figure 2g,h). Interestingly, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image clearly shows that the interlayer spacing in our MoS2 is about 9.3 Å with several nanometers in thickness (Figure 2i), which is much larger than that of standard interlayer spacing (6.2 Å).[53,54] The expanded interlayer spacing in MoS2 may be of great benefit to improving the capability for hosting reversible and fast ion intercalation/ extraction. Thus, the X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to confirm this result further. The obtained XRD patterns are shown in Figure 3a. Compared to the XRD pattern of commercial MoS2 particles (Figure S1, Supporting Information), which is matched well with the standard XRD results (JCPDS No. 75-1539), XRD pattern of the MoS2 @rGO composites is significantly different. Two new diffraction peaks centered at 9.3° and 18.2° correspond to (001) and (002) reflections with d spacings of 9.5 and 4.9 Å, respectively.[43] As for the commercial MoS2 particles, the peak appeared at 14.2° reveals that the d spacing between the Mo planes is only 6.2 Å. A similar phenomenon of the enlarged d spacing can also be found in MoS2 synthesized by the hydrothermal or solvothermal method, and the reason may be attributed to the intercalation of solvent, reaction agent, or their derivatives into two S–Mo–S layers under hightemperature and high-pressure conditions.[43,55,56] To investigate the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area and porous structural characteristics of the MoS2@rGO composite, nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurement was utilized. As illustrated in Figure 3b,c, the BET specific surface area of the MoS2@rGO composite is 79.6 m2 g−1. Meanwhile, according to the Barrett–Joyner– Halenda model, the pore size distribution of the MoS2@rGO composite mostly lies in 2–200 nm range. The relatively high surface area of the MoS2@rGO composite in association with its meso- and macroporous characteristics, benefits electrolyte immersion and rapid K+ diffusion.[57] From the thermogravimetric (TG) analysis (Figure 3d), it can be calculated that the MoS2 content is 87.4% (See Supporting Information). Raman spectra of the MoS2@rGO composite and pure rGO are shown in Figure 3e. Two distinct peaks at 377 and 405 cm−1 correspond to the in-plane Mo–S phonon mode (E12g) and out-ofplane Mo–S mode (A1g) of MoS2, respectively. Furthermore, the intensity of A1g mode is much higher than the E12g mode, revealing that the petal-like MoS2 nanosheets in MoS2@rGO composite consist of very few number of S–Mo–S layers, and own numerous edge-terminated structures,[43,56] which are also favorable for their electrochemical performances (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Additionally, the peaks at 1352 and 1594 cm−1 are the characteristic peaks of the D and G bands from rGO.[58] As we discussed before, interfacial features between the two components in the MoS2@rGO composite is another key to obtain good electrochemical performances. Thus, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out. Overall, the XPS spectrum of the MoS2@rGO composite indicates the existence of Mo, S, O, and C elements
Small 2017, 1701471
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701471 (4 of 8)
in the composites (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Mo3d spectrum (Figure 3f) shows two characteristic peaks of Mo3d3/2 (232.1 eV) and Mo3d5/2 (228.9 eV), indicating the Mo (IV) oxidation state for MoS2.[56] Another weak peak at 226.1 eV ascribes to the S2s component.[50] The peaks at 162.8 and 161.8 eV (Figure 3g) are attributed to the coexistence of S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2.[50] And the peak at 169.1 eV is the small amount of SO42− residues.[56] The peaks for O1s spectrum locate at 533.3, 531.6, and 530.7 eV in Figure 3h are characteristics for COH, CO, and CO bonds, respectively.[50] Noteworthily, it is reported that in the O1s spectrum the COmetal bond is usually located at ≈530–533 eV, and the covalent COM bonding (MCo, Ni, Fe, and Sn) between MxOy and GO has been confirmed in previous works.[59–62] Moreover, it is also reported that the binding energy of COMo bonds are located at 532.4 eV in the high-resolution spectrum of O 1s.[50] Hence, the peak at 532.4 eV is attributed to the COMo bonds. Moreover, it is found that the chemical bonds between MxOy/MxSy and rGO are beneficial for improving the structural stability and electron transport rate.[50,59–62] Figure 3i shows that the C 1s spectra can be decomposed into a dominant peak at 284.7 eV for CC/ CC, while other three weak peaks of oxygen-containing functional groups are at 286.4 eV for CO, 288.1 eV for CO, and 289.0 eV for OCO.[50] In addition, the relatively weak peaks of the C(O)O indicate that the GO sheets have been almost reduced to graphene. Hence, MoS2 and rGO are combined by the COMo bonds, formed by bonding Mo atoms and oxygen-containing functional groups on GO in the MoS2@rGO composite. As a proof-of-concept application, the electrochemical performances of the MoS2@rGO composite as an anode material for nonaqueous KIBs were evaluated (Figure 4). For comparison, the electrochemical performances of the commercial MoS2 particles and pure rGO were also tested. As expected, the MoS2@ rGO composites display an ultrahigh reversible specific capacity of 679 mAh g−1 at the current density of 20 mA g−1, while that of MoS2 and rGO are only 178 and 198 mAh g−1, respectively (Figure 4b). When the current density increased to 50, 100, 200, and 500 mA g−1, the reversible specific capacity of the MoS2@ rGO composites remains 427, 313, 232, and 178 mAh g−1
Small 2017, 1701471
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701471 (5 of 8)
(according to the 15th, 25th, 35th, and 45th charge capacity), respectively, exhibiting excellent rate capability. In striking contrast, they are only about 51, 28, 17, and 5 mAh g−1 for the pure MoS2, as well as 31, 5, 1, and 0.4 mAh g−1 for rGO, respectively, at the same current rates. Moreover, the excellent cycle stability of the MoS2@rGO composites can be observed in Figure 4c. A reversible specific capacity of the MoS2@rGO composites gradually increases from 353 to 491 mAh g−1 within the first 35 cycles at 100 mA g−1 and remains stable until 100 cycles (381 mAh g−1). The increased capacity within the first 35 cycles is speculated to the gradually expanded interlayers of MoS2, and thus providing more active sites for ions storage,[14] as well as the formation of the gel-like polymeric layer or the interfacial ion storage.[50,63–66] After the first 35 cycles, the cell system is stable, so the capacity remained steady for the rest of cycles. To better understand the reason for good performance, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and FESEM of the MoS2@rGO electrode were carried out. The Nyquist plots of MoS2@rGO electrode before and after 100 cycles are shown in Figure S4 in the Supporting Information. Both plots consist of one depressed semicircle in the high-and middle-frequency region and a sloping line in the low-frequency region. Generally, the depressed semicircle is attributed to charge transfer resistance (Rct). After cycling, the Rct value became smaller, implying that the charge transfer in the MoS2@rGO electrode became faster. And as shown in Figure S5 in the Supporting Information, the morphology of the MoS2@rGO electrode has negligible change after 100 cycles, indicating the excellent stability of the electrode. Compared with other reported anode materials for KIBs, such as graphite, KS4 graphite, polynanocrystalline graphite, rGO, few-layered graphene, F-doped graphene foam, soft carbon, hard carbon, hard carbon/carbon black, PTCDA, K2Ti8O17, and Sn/C, the MoS2@rGO composite anode reported here exhibits the one of the best electrochemical performances so far for KIBs (Table 1). The superb overall performance of the MoS2@rGO composites as anode in KIBs can be attributed to the synergistic effect of MoS2 and rGO, the rational and sophisticated material and structure design, with enlarged interlayer spacing of MoS2 for reversible and fast K+ insertion/extraction, strong chemical bonding between MoS2 and rGO for fast electrode kinetics, and excellent endurance of volume expansion during discharge/charge processes, as well as unique nanoarchitectures of MoS2 roses grown upward on the rGO sheets for facilitating electrolyte immersion and reducing ion diffusion paths (Figure 4a). To clarify the electrochemical reaction mechanism of K+ with MoS2, the in situ Raman was conducted to monitor real-time composition evolution of MoS2 upon the initial potassiation/ depotassiation process. Figure 5a,b shows the initial discharge– charge profile of the MoS2@rGO composite at 100 mA g−1 and the corresponding in situ Raman spectra, respectively. At the initial state (open circuit voltage is ≈1.71 V), there are two peaks at 378 and 404 cm−1 acquired from the initial scan. These two peaks belong to the in-plane Mo–S phonon mode (E12g) and out-of-plane Mo–S mode (A1g) of MoS2, respectively. Upon potassium insertion, the peak of A1g mode gradually disappears and the peak of E12g mode shifts to lower frequencies till voltage reaches 0.54 V, revealing that K+ has intercalated into MoS2 to form KxMoS2.[67,68] When the voltage further decreases from 0.54 to 0.01 V, both MoS2 peaks disappear completely, and
Small 2017, 1701471
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701471 (6 of 8)
no any other significant peak can be observed. Encouragingly, this reaction process is reversible during the charging process. The transition from KxMoS2 to MoS2 first occurs at 1.66 V, and then MoS2 gradually recovers with the increase of the voltage. This result can be further verified by the ex situ XRD patterns of the MoS2@rGO composite electrode at different states (Figure 5c). After fully discharged, the characteristic MoS2 peak at 33.2° diminishes, while three peaks at 34.2°, 42.2°, and 49.5° corresponding to (220), (222), and (400) of K2S, respectively appear, indicating the formation of the potassium polysulfide via the conversion reaction at the end of the discharging process. When the cell is fully charged, the characteristic MoS2 peak reoccurs, indicating the good reversibility of this electrochemical reaction of K+ with MoS2.
Based on these in situ and ex situ analysis results, the K+ storage mechanism in the layered metal dichalcogenides of MoS2 can be expressed by a combined K+ intercalation and conversion reaction as follows:
MoS xK xe K MoS (above 0.54 V vs K/K )2 – x 2+ + ←→+ +

sections.heading: K MoS 4 x K (4 x)e
sections.text:
Mo 2K S (below 0.54 V vs K/K )
x 2 + –
2 ( )+ − + − ←→ + +
As a result, the high capacity of the MoS2@rGO composite can be achieved and understood.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, a new synthetic strategy for preparing MoS2@ rGO composites with interesting characteristics for KIBs application has been demonstrated. Specifically, due to the synergistic effect between MoS2 and graphene, the as-synthesized MoS2@rGO composites delivered an ultrahigh initial reversible specific capacity of 679 mAh g−1 at 20 mA g−1. Meanwhile, the initial reversible specific capacity of the composites is 353 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1and remains as high as 381 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles. And these values significantly outperformed previously reported anode materials for KIBs. This work indicates that layered metal dichalcogenides have great potential as advanced electrode materials for high-performance KIBs
Small 2017, 1701471
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701471 (7 of 8)
Small 2017, 1701471
based on the combined K+ intercalation and conversion reaction. It also provides important insights and understanding of advanced KIBs and opens new opportunities for developing less expensive and more efficient next-generation electrochemical energy storage devices.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Synthesis of MoS2@rGO: The GO was fabricated by the modified Hummers’ method.[69] The MoS2@rGO was synthesized via a twostep solvothermal method. First, 25 mg of GO was dispersed in 20 mL deionized water with ultrasonication for 30 min to get a homogeneous solution. Subsequently, 150 mg of MoO3, 10 mL of glycerin, and 30 mL of isopropanol were mixed with the GO solution with ultrasonication for 30 min. The mixture was poured into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 190 °C for 3 h. The brown-black product was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with ethanol, then was mixed with 35 mL of ethanol, 15 mL of deionized water, and 320 mg of thiourea with ultrasonication for 30 min. The mixture was poured into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 200 °C for 12 h. The product was collected by centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times. Then the MoS2@rGO composite was obtained by drying at 80 °C under vacuum for 24 h.
Characterizations: The morphologies and structures of the materials were investigated by FESEM (FEI NanoSEM 450) and TEM (JEOL JEM-2100F). XRD patterns were recorded on an X’Pert PRO MPD diffractometer equipped (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54060 nm). XPS (ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Scientific) was investigated to identify the surface chemistry and Mo-related bond features of the composites. Raman spectra were recorded on Renishaw Invia RM200 with a laser wavelength of 532 nm. In situ Raman spectroscopy was carried out using a modified 2032-coin type cells with a hole drilled at the top. Each scan was collected from 250 to 550 cm−1. The Nitrogen adsorption–desorption and the distribution of pore size were obtained by ASAP-2020 surface area analyzer. The MoS2 content was evaluated by a thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA/SDTA851, Switzerland) in air atmosphere from room temperature to 650 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.
Electrochemical Measurements: The electrode was prepared by mixing the active material, Super P (10 wt%) and poly (vinylidene fluoride) (10 wt%) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone to form a homogeneous slurry, which was spread onto a copper foil and dried at 110 °C under vacuum for 24 h. 2032-coin type cells were assembled in the argon-filled glove box with the as-prepared electrode as the working electrodes, metallic potassium foils as the counter electrodes and reference electrodes, glass fibre membrane (Whatman) as the separator and 0.8 m KPF6 in the mixture of ethylene carbonate and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 in volume) with 2 wt% fluoroethylene carbonate as the electrolyte. Galvanostatic charge–discharge curves were conducted using the LAND CT2001A cell test instrument at different current densities with a voltage window from 0.01 to 3.0 V (vs K+/K). The average mass loading of the rGO, MoS2, and MoS2@rGO was about 1.4 mg cm−2. Galvanostatic charge–discharge curve of the cell for in situ Raman was conducted using the LAND CT2001A cell test instrument at 100 mA g−1 with a voltage window from 0.01 to 3.0 V (vs K+/K). The electrode of ex-XRD test was taken out from the cycled cells in an argon-filled glove box and the DEC was used to wash the electrode several times to remove the electrolyte.
Supporting Information Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.

referenceMentions.context: For example, as a graphitic carbon material, reduced graphene oxide could deliver an initial reversible capacity up to 1057 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 for an NIB,[31] while it is only 222 mAh g−1 at 5 mA g−1 for a KIB, because of the insufficient interlayer distance for K+ insertion/extraction.
